title: Forget lawnmowers: Herd of hungry GOATS to be used to clear weeds at Belgrave Station in Melbourne
text:
A herd of hungry goats will be used to clear out-of-control weeds, berries and grass at a Melbourne train station.

Metro Trains hired six goats from grazing company GrazeAway on Wednesday to eat away overgrown greenery near Belgrave Station.

The living lawnmowers will clear foliage too difficult to uproot by humans without using chemical herbicides, which kill native trees.

GrazeAway goats have been hired to clear excess foliage near Belgrave Station (pictured: goats clearing a site in Wesburn, Victoria)

Up to 30 goats will eventually be deployed at the half-hectare site within the next few months.

Metro's chief operating officer Catherine Baxter told the Herald Sun they had a responsibility to look after the train network in an environmentally friendly way.

'By bringing in goats for weed control, we can allow our native bush to flourish while reducing the need for herbicides, and improve the amenity of the area,' she said.

The goats will be fenced-off and will be provided with water, shelter and vet care.

Goats have also been hired by EastLink and Melbourne Water to solve problems with unwanted foliage.

GrazeAway owner Colin Arnold, who has been running the business for 16 years, said he has seen a significant increase in the demand to hire goats as lawnmowers.
